section.title: Overview
section.para:
A Web application is a collection of HTML/XML documents, Web components (servlets and JSP pages), and other resources such as images and scripts in a directory structure. &framework-name; libraries support using different methodologies based on different building blocks such as JSP pages, custom tags, JavaBeans components, and servlets to produce a web application that delivers dynamically generated content. &framework-name;.
Based on application requirements, developers can pursue a design which is purely servlet based or they can pursue a design which is a combination of JSPs and servlets (also known as the Model 2 design). &framework-name; also provides a more XML-centric approach where most business logic can be defined with the forms themselves so that the JSPs can purely concentrate on the presentation.

This chapter describes the different approaches described above so that developers can choose dependent upon application specific requirements. The different approaches have their own benefits and failings and it is up to the developer to decide which is the best way to use to create and deliver a web application.

section.title: Servlets
section.para:
Although JSP pages can be used for most presentation purposes, there are some circumstances such as low-level application functions that don't require frequent modification where servlets are more appropriate. Thus &framework-name; does not restrict the use of Servlets and fully supports both servlets and JSPs.
Following the common web application atchitecture, all custom servlet Java classes must exist under web-app/Site/WEB-INF/classes (if JAR files are used, they must exist under web-app/Site/WEB-INF/lib directory).
Servlets are named and mapped in Site/WEB-INF/web.xml as shown below:
<servlet> <servlet-name>Navigator</servlet-name> <servlet-class>com.xaf.navigate.NavigateFileSystemServlet</servlet-class> </servlet> <servlet-mapping> <servlet-name>Navigator</servlet-name> <url-pattern>/navigate/*</url-pattern> </servlet-mapping>
The above example is a built-in navigation servlet provided by &framework-name; and can be used to display directory listings.

All pages created using com.xaf.page.AbstractServletPage as a super class must be registered so that they can be navigated to through a servlet. &framework-name; provides a servlet class called com.xaf.page.PageControllerServlet. This servlet class contains a method called registerPages which is used to register the Java defined web pages. For example, &explorer-name; registers its pages through a servlet called com.xaf.ace.AppComponentsExplorerServlet and the servlet is registered in web.xml:
<servlet> <servlet-name>AppComponentsExplorer</servlet-name> <servlet-class>com.xaf.ace.AppComponentsExplorerServlet</servlet-class> </servlet> <servlet-mapping> <servlet-name>AppComponentsExplorer</servlet-name> <url-pattern>/ace/*</url-pattern> </servlet-mapping>

section.title: Java Server Pages (JSP)
section.para:
All JSP files (or the directories in which they reside) must exist under web-app/Site directory. &product-name; provides several custom tags for use and they are defined in web-app/Site/WEB-INF/tld/xaf.tld:
Custom Tags
xaf:dialog
Represents a dialog defined in /WEB-INF/ui/dialogs.xml. The following attributes are available:
name,
source,
skin,
listener
Refer to for details on how to use this custom tag.
xaf:query
Represents a static query defined in /WEB-INF/sql/statements.xml. The following attributes are available:
name,
dataSource,
stmtSource,
report,
skin,
store,
storeType,
debug,
listener.
Refer to for details on how to use this custom tag.
xaf:dml
Represents a data manipulating action such as inserts, deletes, and modifications. The following attributes are available:
name
dataSource
debug,
command,
table,
fields,
columns,
where,
context,
insertchk,
updatechk.
Refer to for details on how to use this custom tag.
xaf:transaction
Represents a database transaction. The following attributes are available: dataSource.
xaf:query-select-dialog
Represents a dynamic query definition dialog. The following attributes are available:
name: Name of the select-dialog defined in the web-app/Site/WEB-INF/sql/statement.xml
source:
skin: Name of the skin defined in the web-app/Site/WEB-INF/ui/dialog.xml
Refer to for details on how to use this custom tag.
